column1: Wolfenbüttel (German pronunciation: [ˌvɔlfn̩ˈbʏtl̩]) is a town in Lower Saxony
column3: the administrative capital of Wolfenbüttel District. It is best known as the location of the internationally renowned Herzog August Library and for having the largest concentration of timber-framed buildings in Germany. It is an episcopal see of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Brunswick. It is also home to the Jägermeister distillery
column4: houses a campus of the Ostfalia University of Applied Sciences
column5: and the Landesmusikakademie of Lower Saxony.

column1: The town center is located at an elevation of 77 ft (23 m) on the Oker river near the confluence with its Altenau tributary
column2: about 13 km (8.1 mi) south of Brunswick and 60 km (37 mi) southeast of the state capital Hannover. Wolfenbüttel is situated about half-way between the Harz mountain range in the south and the Lüneburg Heath in the north. The Elm-Lappwald Nature Park and the Asse hill range stretch east and southeast of the town.

column3: Wolfenbüttel is part of the Hannover–Braunschweig–Göttingen–Wolfsburg Metropolitan Region. It is the southernmost of the 172 towns in Northern Germany whose names end in büttel

column1: The mayor of the town Wolfenbüttel since 2006 is Thomas Pink. He was reelected in 2014 with 67.7% of the vote. In August 2018 he left the German Christian Democratic Union party.

column2: probably restricted to a tiny islet in the Oker river
column3: was founded in the tenth century. It was mentioned in 1118 as Wulferisbuttle
column4: when the Saxon count Widekind of Wolfenbüttel had a water castle erected on the important trade route from Brunswick to Halberstadt and Leipzig. Destroyed by Henry the Lion in 1191
column5: and again by his great-grandson Duke Albert I of Brunswick-Lüneburg in 1255

column2: the town had become the permanent residence of the Brunswick Princes of Wolfenbüttel. Devastated in the 1542 Schmalkaldic War
column3: it was largely rebuilt in a Renaissance style under Duke Julius of Brunswick-Lüneburg
column4: including several gracht waterways laid out by Hans Vredeman de Vries. The duke vested the citizens with market rights in 1570 and founded the Ducal Library (Herzogliche Bibliothek
column5: the later Bibliotheca Augusta) two years later.

column2: Danish troops under King Christian IV occupied the fortified town in 1626. Upon the nearby Battle of Lutter
column3: they were besieged by the Imperial forces of General Gottfried Heinrich Graf zu Pappenheim. Re-conquered in 1627
column4: the Wolfenbüttel fortress remained under the command of Gottfried Huyn von Geleen. In June 1641 the Battle of Wolfenbüttel was fought here
column5: when the Swedish forces under Wrangel and the Count of Königsmark defeated the Austrians under Archduke Leopold of Habsburg

column1: Wolfenbüttel hosted the three-day International German Bus Pulling Championships in May 2009
column2: where five-person teams pull a 16-ton bus 30 meters.Every year starting in late November
column3: Wolfenbüttel stages a Christmas market with food and drinks. Locals often come and enjoy the pre-Christmas Atmosphere.
